topic_seeds.description: Being overly critical of oneself (complex, layered situation)
Adjusting to a new location or environment
Providing minimal context about their situation (complex, layered situation)

flaw_patterns.name: flat_affect
flaw_patterns.description: Describes heavy things without apparent emotion

flaw_patterns.name: seeking_reassurance
flaw_patterns.description: Wants to be told it's fine rather than exploring

flaw_patterns.name: mood_dependent_recall
flaw_patterns.description: Current mood colors memory of past

exchanges.user:
So I'm not even sure why I'm doing this, honestly. My therapist suggested it but I don't really know what to expect. 

I guess the main thing is I've been really hard on myself lately. Like, at work I made this mistake in a presentation last month and I still think about it constantly. It was small, nothing anyone else probably even noticed, but I keep replaying it. And then I start thinking about all the other times I've messed up, going back years, and it just spirals. My partner says I'm being ridiculous but that just makes me feel worse because then I'm upset at myself for being upset at myself, you know?

Also been having some weird health stuff. Nothing serious probably. Just like, I'll get a pain somewhere and immediately assume it's something bad, Google it at 2am, and then I can't sleep. Started happening more since the move last year. The move itself went fine, we like the new place, but maybe that whole process just stressed me out more than I thought.

Anyway. Yeah. Not sure what I'm supposed to do here. Is this where I just talk about my week or what?
exchanges.assistant:
I'm glad you're here, even if it feels uncertain right now. Let me jump into what you shared.

**The self-criticism loop:** A mistake from a month ago that you're still replaying—plus the spiral into old mistakes—that's exhausting. And then the layer on top where you're criticizing yourself for criticizing yourself? That's a really common trap, but it doesn't make it less painful. What specifically goes through your mind when you replay that presentation moment? Like, what does your mind say happened, or what it means about you?

**Health anxiety and Googling at 2am:** That pattern of pain → catastrophic assumption → late-night Google spiral is rough, and it sounds like it's gotten worse since the move. You said the move went fine, but a big life change can leave residue even when the logistics go smoothly. What kind of pains are we talking about—like, are they random, or do they show up in similar situations or times of day?

**What to expect here:** This isn't a script. Some people come in with a specific thing they want to work on, others just need space to think out loud. You can talk about your week if that's useful, or we can dig into something that's been bothering you, or we can look for patterns in what's happening. It's really up to you—what would feel most helpful right now?

exchanges.user:
yeah so i've been thinking about the presentation thing since you asked. honestly it's stupid. i made a typo on one slide, said "2024" instead of "2023" when i was talking about quarterly results. literally caught it myself like ten seconds later and corrected it. but my brain won't let it go. keeps telling me everyone thought i was incompetent, even though logically i know that's not true. my partner didn't even remember it happened until i brought it up again.

the health stuff got a bit better actually. had that sharp pain in my side again last week and instead of immediately spiraling i just... waited? it went away after like an hour. so maybe that's progress or whatever. though now i'm worried about this thing on my neck that's probably just a lymph node but it's been there for a while and i keep touching it which probably makes it worse.

also we're thinking about going back to visit my parents next month and honestly i'm dreading it. they're fine but my mom has a way of making me feel like i'm doing everything wrong. work, the move, my health anxiety (though she doesn't know about the 2am google sessions), all of it. she'll ask how things are going and then comment on whatever i say. last time we went she mentioned my weight like three times in a weekend. so now i'm already working myself up about it even though it's weeks away. which is dumb because i can't change anything by worrying about it now.

anyway that's what's going on.
exchanges.assistant:
**The presentation typo:** You called it stupid, but I'm noticing something—you corrected it in ten seconds, your partner didn't even remember it, and yet your brain is still holding it as evidence that everyone thought you were incompetent. That gap between what actually happened (quick correction, no one cared) and what your mind insists happened (public humiliation) is worth paying attention to. When you replay it, does your mind show you the correction part, or does it just loop the mistake? And what does "incompetent" mean to your brain—like, what's the fear underneath that word?

**Health anxiety shift:** Waiting out the side pain instead of spiraling—that's genuinely progress. Your brain offered you the usual catastrophe script and you didn't take it. The lymph node thing is tricky because touching it keeps it on your radar, which feeds the loop. One thing that might help: notice when you're touching it, and see if there's a pattern—like, does it happen more when you're stressed about something else, or bored, or right before bed? Sometimes the touching is less about the lymph node and more about giving your anxiety something to do.

**Dreading the parent visit:** Your mom makes comments about your weight, your choices, how things are going—and now you're already bracing for it weeks out. That pre-emptive dread is doing the damage early. You said "I can't change anything by worrying about it now," which is true, but I'm curious: if you weren't spending energy on dread, what would you want to be different about the visit itself? Like, is there a version of that trip where you feel less beaten up by her comments, or is the goal just to survive it?

exchanges.user:
ugh ok so i kept catching myself touching the neck thing and yeah, there's definitely a pattern. mostly happens when i'm sitting at my desk working, or like scrolling at night when my brain is tired. so basically when i'm bored or stressed. which makes sense i guess.

anyway that's not really what's on my mind today. the presentation thing has been bugging me differently. i was in a meeting yesterday and someone else made like an actual mistake—forgot to include a whole data set in their analysis—and everyone just moved on. no big deal. and i'm sitting there thinking about how i'm still mad at myself over a typo from a month ago while this person just... exists without spiraling. why does my brain do that? like logically i can see it's ridiculous but knowing that doesn't actually help.

also been thinking about what you said about my mom and the visit. i don't really know what a version where i feel "less beaten up" looks like tbh. she's always going to comment. that's just who she is. i guess maybe i just need to not care as much? but i don't know how to make myself not care when she says stuff. it's not like i'm choosing to feel bad about it.
exchanges.assistant:
**The neck-touching pattern:** Yeah, desk work and night scrolling—both low-key stress states where your mind isn't fully occupied. The touching gives your anxiety a job. Now that you see the pattern, you could try something small: next time you catch yourself doing it, just notice it without judgment ("oh, there's the touching thing again") and see if you can redirect your hand to something neutral—hold a pen, rest it on your lap, whatever. Not about stopping it perfectly, just giving yourself a different option when you notice.

**Why your brain holds onto the typo while others move on:** This is the question, right? You watched someone make a bigger mistake and get zero internal punishment, while you're still prosecuting yourself over something minor from a month ago. Here's what might be happening: your brain has a belief about what mistakes mean—maybe that they expose you as a fraud, or that people are keeping score, or that you have to be perfect to be acceptable. So when you make a mistake, even tiny ones, your brain treats it like evidence of something much bigger and scarier. When someone else makes a mistake, your brain doesn't apply that same story to them because it's not about *them*. It's about you and whatever your brain thinks you have to prove or protect. What comes up when I say that? Does any part of that land, or does it feel off?

**Your mom and "just not caring":** You can't logic yourself into not caring—that's not how feelings work, and you're right that you're not choosing to feel bad when she comments. But there might be a different move here. Right now it sounds like the only options are: 1) she comments and you absorb it and feel bad, or 2) magically stop caring (which feels impossible). What if there's a third option—she comments, you feel the feeling, *and* you don't let it become a referendum on whether you're doing life right? Like, she says something about your weight, you feel the sting, and then you remind yourself: "That's her opinion, not a fact about my worth." It doesn't erase the feeling, but it might keep it from burrowing in the way it usually does. Does that distinction make sense, or does it still feel too abstract?

exchanges.user:
been a weird few days. so i tried the whole "notice the touching without judgment" thing and honestly it helped more than i expected? like i still catch myself doing it but now i'm aware of it happening instead of just realizing an hour later that i've been touching my neck the whole time. small thing but whatever, it feels different.

the bigger thing though is work has been kind of a mess. got feedback on a project and it wasn't bad, just... fine. competent. and my immediate reaction was relief that i didn't screw it up, which then made me realize how much of my brain is just bracing for failure all the time. like that's exhausting and i didn't even notice it was happening until i felt the relief. so now i'm hyper aware of it which is its own kind of annoying.

also about the mom thing - i don't know if the "that's her opinion not a fact" approach will actually work but i'm going to try it when we visit. though honestly i'm already dreading it less just because we talked about it? idk that's weird. like nothing has actually changed about the visit but my brain feels slightly less wound up about it.

anyway. the presentation stuff is still there but it's quieter now. some days i barely think about it.
exchanges.assistant:
**The neck-touching awareness:** That shift from "realizing an hour later" to "noticing it happening"—that's actually significant. You're building what's called metacognitive awareness, which is just a fancy way of saying you can watch your own patterns in real time now. That creates space to do something different, which you're already doing. Not a small thing.

**The "competent" feedback and bracing for failure:** This is a really important catch. You got fine feedback and your first feeling was *relief*—not pride, not satisfaction, just "thank god I didn't mess up." That tells you how much energy your brain is spending on threat detection, waiting for the other shoe to drop. And yeah, now that you see it, you can't unsee it, which feels annoying but it's actually the first step. You can't change a pattern you don't notice. What does that bracing feel like in your body when you're waiting for feedback or going into a meeting? Like, is it tension somewhere, shallow breathing, mental rehearsal of worst-case scenarios?

**Mom visit dread easing:** Sometimes naming the thing and having a plan—even a loose one—takes the edge off because your brain stops spinning in "how do I handle this?" mode. You gave it an answer ("I'll remind myself it's her opinion, not a fact"), and even if you're not sure it'll work, your brain has something to do besides catastrophize. That's not weird, that's actually how anticipatory anxiety works. The dread often isn't about the event itself, it's about feeling helpless in the face of it.

**Presentation quieting down:** Some days you barely think about it. Notice that—your brain is starting to let it go, which means it's losing its power as "definitive evidence of your incompetence." That's the spiral unwinding.

exchanges.user:
so the visit happened. it was... fine? like not great but not a disaster either. my mom did the thing where she commented on my appearance like twice, and i tried that "that's her opinion not a fact" thing and honestly it helped. not in a magical way but i noticed i wasn't spiraling about it the way i usually do. just kind of let it sit there and moved on. my partner even said i seemed less reactive than normal.

but here's the thing that's actually bothering me now. my mom asked how work was going and i mentioned the project feedback i got, said it went well. and she immediately pivoted to "well you should be aiming higher, you're capable of more than just competent." and like, i KNOW she's just being my mom and probably doesn't realize how that lands, but it hit different this time. because i'd just started feeling okay about the feedback being fine, you know? and then suddenly it's like, fine isn't good enough. and now i'm back in that loop of "i should be doing better, i'm settling, i'm not living up to potential."

the weird part is i can see the pattern happening in real time. like i KNOW my brain is doing the thing where one comment rewires what i thought about my own work. but knowing that doesn't seem to stop it from happening. which is frustrating.

also on the health anxiety front, it's been pretty quiet actually. barely thought about the neck thing in like two weeks. so that's something.
exchanges.assistant:
**The visit and your mom's comments:** The fact that you could let her appearance comments sit there without spiraling—and your partner noticed you were less reactive—that's real progress. You're building a different relationship with her opinions, where they can land without becoming internal verdicts. That's not magical, you're right, but it's the actual work.

**The "aiming higher" comment:** This one hit harder because of the timing. You'd just gotten to a place where "competent" feedback felt okay, maybe even good enough, and then she said it wasn't. And now your brain is back in the loop: *fine isn't good enough, I'm settling, I'm not living up to potential.* Here's what I'm noticing—when she said that, whose voice did it sound like? Like, was it a new criticism, or did it land hard because it echoed something your brain already says to you? Because if your brain already has a track running about "you should be doing more," her comment didn't create that loop, it just turned the volume way up on something that was already there.

The frustrating part is you can see the pattern happening in real time but can't stop it. That makes sense, though—awareness doesn't automatically equal control. Right now you're in the "noticing" phase, which feels useless because the loop still runs. But noticing is actually the prerequisite for the next move, which is: when the loop starts ("fine isn't good enough"), you get to ask it some questions. Like: *Good enough for what? Whose standard is this? What would 'aiming higher' actually look like, and do I even want that, or is this just anxiety dressed up as ambition?* You don't have to have answers yet, but you can start questioning whether the loop is telling you something true or just something loud.

**Health anxiety quiet for two weeks:** Yeah, that's something. Your brain found a different place to put its energy, and the neck thing lost its grip. Worth noticing that when you're not feeding the loop (touching, checking, Googling), it fades.

exchanges.user:
been a couple weeks since the visit and honestly the whole "questioning the loop" thing has been rattling around in my head. like i can't stop thinking about it but not in a productive way. more like my brain is stuck on the idea that maybe i'm just... mediocre? like what if the loop isn't anxiety, what if it's just reality telling me i'm not that ambitious or driven or whatever, and i'm using "anxiety" as an excuse to not push myself harder.

anyway that's not what i wanted to talk about actually. work has been fine, health stuff is still quiet. but i've noticed something weird with my partner. we've been together for like eight years and i think maybe i've been kind of... dismissive? when they try to tell me about their day or their stuff, i'm not really listening, just kind of waiting for my turn to talk about whatever's on my mind or making it about me somehow. they haven't said anything but i can feel it. and i realize that's probably because i'm so in my own head about work and my mom and all of it that there's just no room for anything else. which sucks because they've actually been really supportive through all this and i'm just kind of... checked out.

is that something worth looking at or am I spiraling about a new thing now? i genuinely can't tell if i'm having a real insight or just finding a new way to be hard on myself.
exchanges.assistant:
**The "maybe I'm just mediocre" spiral:** This is your brain doing something sneaky—it took the questioning tool I offered and turned it into a new weapon against yourself. Instead of questioning whether the loop is *true*, your brain flipped it to "what if the loop is reality and I'm just making excuses?" That's not insight, that's the same self-criticism wearing a different costume. Here's a question to test it: if you were genuinely mediocre and unambitious, would you be spending this much energy wondering if you're mediocre and unambitious? Mediocre people don't typically agonize over whether they're living up to their potential. Your brain isn't telling you the truth here—it's just found a new angle to make you feel bad.

**Noticing the pattern with your partner:** This feels different from the spiral stuff, and I think you're right to pay attention to it. You said you're waiting for your turn to talk, making their stuff about you, checked out even though they've been supportive—and you noticed it yourself before they said anything. That's not spiraling, that's actual self-awareness. The fact that you're asking "is this real or am I just being hard on myself?" makes sense, because your brain has taught you to doubt your own observations. But here's the thing: you described specific behaviors (not listening, waiting for your turn, making it about you) and a specific consequence (feeling the distance between you two). That's concrete, not abstract self-attack. It's worth looking at.

What would it look like to check this with them directly? Not in a "sorry I'm terrible" way, but more like: "Hey, I've noticed I've been pretty in my own head lately and I'm worried I haven't been really present when you're talking about your stuff. Have you felt that too?" That opens the door for them to tell you what they're actually experiencing instead of you just running the story in your head. And if they say yeah, they've felt it—then you have real information to work with instead of just guilt. Does that feel doable, or does it bring up something else?
